Most platforms claim 'Bitcoin security' but use Proof-of-Stake, bridges, or economic assumptions. Syscoin IS Bitcoin security via merged mining Proof-of-Work.

This thread: Why direct hashpower inheritance beats every alternative. And why young builders recognize this. üßµ 
Let's start with what 'Bitcoin-adjacent' actually means: platforms that reference Bitcoin in marketing but use completely different security models.

PoS validator sets. Bridge trust assumptions. Economic incentive alignment. These aren't Bitcoin security. They're separate systems.
Bitcoin-centered means: direct security inheritance through merged mining.

When F2Pool, ViaBTC, or AntPool mine Bitcoin, they simultaneously secure Syscoin. Same computational work. Same cryptographic proof. Same attack cost. This is actual Bitcoin security. Not adjacent. Direct.
Why does this matter? Because the security you inherit can't be faked. Attack Syscoin and you need Bitcoin-level computational resources. No economic assumptions. No validator compromises. No bridge exploits.

Physical barrier requiring Bitcoin hashpower. 11 years proves it works.
Honduras November 2025: Government deployed ballot attestation on Syscoin during contested election.

Why? Because when electoral integrity matters, you don't trust economic assumptions. You trust mathematics. Bitcoin PoW via merged mining delivers cryptographic proof governments need.
Fresh generation notices this. 200-400+ young developers per event across dozens of LATAM and Africa countries. They evaluated PoS platforms promising easy scaling. They chose Bitcoin-secured PoW.

Why? Because government validation signals: this survives pressure.
The Forge approaches Q1 2026: DeFi, NFT, staking, trading, swapping experiences rewarding ecosystem participation. Young developers are building this infrastructure on a Bitcoin-secured foundation. Users arriving soon to government-validated architecture.

This is why inheritance matters.
Competitive reality: Platforms claiming 'Bitcoin security' through PoS, bridges, or Proof of Transfer use Bitcoin's NAME. Syscoin via merged mining uses Bitcoin's HASHPOWER.

According to PlanB:

The four-year cycle and the Stock-to-Flow (S2F) model are two different concepts.
The four-year cycle is an empirical observation that the year following a halving tends to be bullish, but 2025 did not fit this pattern.

S2F, on the other hand, is not a model designed to identify bull or bear markets, nor market tops or bottoms. It is based on the hypothesis that scarcity drives value. Under this framework, Bitcoin is scarcer than gold and could ultimately be worth more than gold.

S2F is intended to capture the average price over a four-year cycle. The current cycle‚Äôs average is around $90,000, significantly higher than the previous cycle‚Äôs average of about $34,000. From this perspective, PlanB argues there is room for Bitcoin to move into a $250,000 to $1,000,000 range over the next two years.

As a long-term premise, he says he still believes in this model.

Bitcoin‚Äôs Mid-January Rebound: A Structural Look at Macro Relief, ETF Flows, and Short Covering via @cryptoquant_com (Analysis Report No. 179)

The Bitcoin price increase observed on January 14‚Äì15 is best interpreted as a rebound within an existing range following a corrective phase, rather than the start of a new structural uptrend. Over the prior two months, Bitcoin had traded in high-level consolidation, with selling pressure near the upper range and demand emerging on pullbacks. Although prices weakened briefly in early January, there was no clear evidence of large-scale long-term holder distribution or a structural deterioration in supply-demand conditions.

The dominant explanation for this move is that spot demand and leverage unwinding occurred simultaneously under a temporarily stabilized external environment. On January 13, U.S. CPI data came in broadly in line with market expectations, easing concerns about renewed inflation acceleration and further rapid monetary tightening. This reduced macro-driven downside pressure and allowed internal market dynamics to play a larger role in price formation.

In parallel, progress reported in the U.S. Congress on digital asset market structure legislation, commonly referred to as the CLARITY Act, contributed to a stabilization in market sentiment by reducing regulatory uncertainty, even though it was not a direct short-term price catalyst.

Within this context, inflows into U.S. spot Bitcoin ETFs provided the initial upward impulse. As prices approached the upper end of the range, short liquidations in the derivatives market accelerated the move through forced buybacks. The recovery in the Coinbase Premium Gap suggests that U.S.-based spot demand strengthened during this period.

At present, this price action is best viewed as a demand-driven rebound within a range. If spot demand weakens again, this interpretation would need to be reassessed.

$BTC All the short liquidations that happened since yesterday on the traders‚Äô side are actually very easy to understand.


When the majority of people have the idea that BTC will go to 70k, that same majority opens massive short positions. This is very often used by big players to liquidate traders on a large scale.


Many traders short every red candle, and then they get caught by violent rebounds.


It‚Äôs important to understand the system: the 70k zone is a trap support ü™§, created to trigger emotions among traders. These emotions push them to open millions in short positions. This benefits the big players, because it becomes easy money to liquidate with only a small amount of liquidity injected into the market, allowing them to make even more profit.


That‚Äôs why the market will never drop in a straight line to 70k. They will always exploit massive liquidations on both sides (long and short) until traders no longer have enough money to keep shorting.


Only then will they use other strategies to reach their main objective.


For now, the market is highly manipulated and full of traps.

1/8

5/8
üá≥üá¨ Nigeria

New tax law requires crypto exchanges to link transactions to tax IDs and national ID numbers starting Jan. 1. Virtual asset providers must file customer data and transaction details with tax authorities. Identity-based model replaces blockchain surveillance and aligns with OECD's global Crypto-Asset Reporting Framework.

6/8
üá¶üá™ UAE

Dubai's DFSA scraps token whitelist, shifts vetting to licensed firms in DIFC free zone. Companies now assess token suitability under principles-based rules. Privacy coins like Monero and Zcash face tougher internal scrutiny despite no explicit ban. VARA maintains direct prohibition authority outside DIFC.

7/8

As U.S.‚ÄìIran tensions rise, Washington has quietly begun relocating and advising the withdrawal of personnel across key Middle East bases. These are costly, operational moves ‚Äî not headline theater ‚Äî yet they stop short of confirming an imminent strike.

The market-relevant question is not whether a strike happens ‚Äî but what kind of escalation follows.

A limited, time-bounded action that avoids energy disruption could be absorbed quickly, especially if global liquidity conditions remain supportive. In that scenario, Bitcoin can continue to behave like a non-sovereign macro hedge.

But escalation that threatens oil supply, strengthens the dollar, or tightens global financial conditions would pressure leveraged positioning across all risk assets ‚Äî crypto included.

What matters next is not a single headline, but whether precautionary moves turn into sustained force posture changes and whether official messaging converges or stays deliberately ambiguous.

The next move won‚Äôt be decided by rhetoric, but by how far escalation actually goes.

What Are Bonds & Why They Matter

Bonds are debt instruments. When you buy a bond, you‚Äôre lending money to a government or company in exchange for fixed interest payments and the return of your principal at maturity. They‚Äôre less volatile than stocks or crypto and are often used for stability and income.

Bond prices move opposite to interest rates, making them a key signal for inflation, central bank policy, and market sentiment. When yields are high, investors favor bonds over risk assets. When yields fall, capital often flows back into stocks and crypto.

Understanding bonds helps explain why money shifts between traditional markets and digital assets.

Bitcoin and Ampleforth represent opposite philosophies in monetary design.

Bitcoin fixes supply. Only 21 million coins will ever exist. That certainty makes it an excellent long-term store of value, but it also means the price must absorb every change in demand.

When demand spikes or collapses, volatility is the mechanism that clears the market.

AMPL is different. Instead of fixing supply, it fixes a target: a purchasing power reference point.

When demand rises, supply expands. When demand falls, supply contracts. The result is not price rigidity, but volatility redistribution across balances rather than into price alone.

Of course, like anything, this has tradeoffs.

Elastic supply challenges intuition, complicates accounting, and breaks simple ‚Äúnumber go up‚Äù narratives.

But it also unlocks something Bitcoin cannot: a native, non-custodial asset designed to behave more like commodity money than speculative equity.

Bitcoin optimizes for scarcity.
AMPL optimizes for monetary stability.

They are not competitors; they are more like opposites, solving different problems at the base layer of crypto money.
